The GoPicnic ExploreMunch box contains an interesting collection of individual snacks.  Almost all of them were good by themselves, with the exception perhaps of the turkey stick which I thought was too dry and was overly spiced.  I have never seen the green pea snacks or the sunflower cubes before.  Both were good.The collection reminded me of the snack meals provided by airlines just before they stopped providing meals at all.  To their credit, GoPicnic has worked to avoid including artificial colors and flavors.  The collapsible spork was a neat touch, although a spoon would have worked just as well for the apple sauce.Each of the items was individually wrapped.  Some of the wrappers were difficult for me, an adult, to open.  I think that children might have trouble also.  In the end, you are left with a very large pile of wrappers.  This is probably not a good lesson in using resources.Taken as a whole, the box was an interesting idea, but seemed to miss the mark as a meal.

I'm not a fan of rice pasta, corn is my preferred. And this stuff is fantastic. The gluten free pastas seem to be a little harder to get the perfect level of doneness, but that's a cooking issue not a product issue.  This pasta is good and holds up well and firm, unlike rice pasta which - in my experience - just seems to fall apart.

My husband loves this cereal.  It's not always worth buying it on Amazon so I watch the prices to be sure it's worth it.  With the Subscribe & Save and grouping my orders to get the best discount, it helps the pricing.
It tastes decent when freshly cooked. It takes over 20 minutes to cook, and I eat my pasta al dente. Also, it reheats very poorly; my pasta winds up gummy.

In my opinion, this is the best gluten-free flour in the market!  I've tried pretty much every type and I have never had a recipe fail using this flour cup per cup.  I take a regular recipe and use this flour, and the only change I make is to add more spices or more vanilla and baking soda or powder than a regular recipe calls for.  I've been buying this for a couple of years, and am so happy Amazon carries it now!!Donna Spencer

About 5 years ago I discovered the "secret" to better baking -- parchment paper.  This little kitchen miracle worker makes baking so much easier and healthier.  No more having to grease cookie sheets or clean up the mess from a pecan pie that "bubbled over" when cooking.  A piece of parchment paper does the trick while keeping unecessary fats and calories out of your foods!The one problem with parchment paper is the variety you find in most stores is 1)  Expensive and 2)  bleached with chemicals.  "If You Care" has solved both of those problems in this 4-pack of parchment paper that your kitchen will love (hint:  it also makes a GREAT gift for a friend who is into cooking -- trust me!).  For the price you will pay for 4 boxes of this parchment paper you will get over 8 times as much as you would have gotten in the grocery store!  Plus you can rest easy knowing you aren't harming the environment by using paper that was bleached (can someone tell me what the purpose is to bleaching parchment paper -- it just seems silly!)I can't stop recommending this paper enough.  This is my 4th purchase from Amazon over the years of this exact same paper and while you may think that 4 boxes is a lot -- trust me, it will get used!  Once you discover how much easier it makes cooking you will be using it for everything!
summary: For cooks who love to COOK!

However, the kids really loved these and there weren't any left over for anyone else to taste test by the time they were done snacking.  I think this would be a great snack for a chocoholic.

reviewText: There are a LOT of almonds, pumpkin seeds and nuts in this snack mix which is so nice, since typically trail mixes are heavy on cheap nuts like peanuts and too many raisins.  This is a good and hearty snack mix with plenty of dried blueberries - my favorite part of the mix! So many trail mixes are mostly full of raisins - but this mix has a generous amount of berries and good quality organic nuts - it is a great price and I put it on my Subscribe and Save list.I use this mix as a base for cookie dough - a great short cut for cookie baking.I love all products made by Eden Natural Foods.  This company was a pionner in the beginning days of the organic food industry.  Founded in the late 1960's (forgot exact date, ooops) by Michael Potter.  I've been eating 100% organic since 1969 and it i so unfortunate 95% of big national organic food companies have been sold to Pillsbury, Kraft, General Mills, Kellogg - Odwalla Juice is owned by Coca cola, Naked Juice owned by Kraft, a very long list and the saddest one is Burts Bee's was sold to Clorox (ugh!).  Eden is one of the very few big national organic food companies which refused to sell out to huge corporations which make junk food.  I admire the integrity of Eden Foods and have been a customer since they were founded a zillion years ago!Check out Eden brand dried Montmorency organic dried cherries - phenomenal - plus they make Montmorency organic jam spread and Eden cherry juice - unfiltered and very intense flavor which is SO rich I dilute it with some spring water.  Michigan is known as growing the best cherries in America, if not the world - and Eden Foods is in Clinton Michigan so the crop is harvested and then turned into product quickly - exceptionally good flavor!
summary: Great Snack - 100% Organic - Lots of Berries and Nuts

reviewText: so they never really feel cooked to me.  It did come with the premium little fishcakes and nori pouches, so that is kind of fun.personally, i like well-done noodles, so this was a bit chewy for my tastes.  gave one to a friend, they didn't much care for it either.  was worth a try however!

With the health benefits of organic cinnamon/honey etc. this is a great addition to my pantry. I will buy more when I run out of this product.

In late 2011, I completely changed my lifestyle and started eating healthier. Along the way, I have read many websites and talked with nutritionists as well as my trainer about various ways of cooking and items to use, one of which was coconut oil. I originally purchased some organic coconut oil from Kroger and was shocked when I had such a hard time getting it out of the jar. I was hoping this product would be different, but it is exactly the same. Trying to measure out a tablespoon or two is a ridiculously difficult chore; you basically have to scrape away at it until you have roughly what you want.The coconut oil I originally purchased also had the actual taste of coconut, so I am not completely sure what prevents this one from having any flavor. From reading online, the only conclusion I came come to is it has been more refined/processed. I realize that everything which has "organic" on the label does not necessarily mean it is good for you. It is simply one of the newer marketing tricks to make consumers believe they are purchasing something "healthy" and/or to simply charge more.Nonetheless, coconut oil is better for you than many of the typical alternatives but this particular brand would not be one I would purchase in the future because of being more refined/processed in combination with the considerably higher price.

These are very good for a low carb and gluten free treat.  The downside is that they are quite dry (though I know many people like dry cookies), they are fine when dipped in coffee.  Also, I think these would be much, much better if Julian Bakery doubled or tripled the amount of ginger in them, because A: they're a bit too weak on the ginger flavor and B: it would help cover the unfavorable psyllium flavor
summary: Good cookies, glad they're low carb, could be improved a little

reviewText: Cannot find Simply Organic Pepper locally any more. To be honest, I'm not much of a pepper lover. I don't grind it fresh or buy exotic peppercorns. My whole life I thought pepper tasted a bit like wood or dust, so I never really developed a palate for it. Surprise, surprise! Dust is what stale or cheap pepper tastes like! When I tasted the medium grind Simply Organic pepper, I actually started to really like pepper. But fresh ground pepper is often still too sharp and overpowering for me. The medium grind Simply Organic is still very flavorful but with less of a bite and no dusty flavor whatsoever. Tastes wonderful both in cooking and sprinkled!

This "syrup" is not very sweet and despite being labelled "sweetened with splenda" it has a very small amount as splenda is the last ingredient. The primary sweetner is acsulfame potassium which is nowhere as far as i am concerned. As a general rule if any deception in ingredients or labelling the product should be boycotted. Who wants to buy products from companies that want to deceive you into buying an inferior or cheaply made product. They find it easier to put a token amount of splenda so they can put it on the label and you will think better of the product. I only would buy this if there was no alternative available and it was necessary due to blood sugar level control otherwise pass on it. I hate food companies that lie. Even small lies. It is like a famous brand of shortening on the market that says 0 grams of trans fats on the label but in reality it is 100 percent hydrogenated oil which is trans fat. Even though the entire can is only trans fat they made the serving size so small that it contains less than 1 gram of trans fat so they can put contains 0 grams trans fat on the label to cheat their customers by deception.  Torani sugar free syrup would not sell much if they put sweetened with acsulfame potassium on the front of the bottle instead of splenda. Nuff said.
summary: Not very sweet, splenda is minor ingredient

reviewText: I picked up a bottle of "Aloe Gloe" Aloe Water on a whim, after I noticed something unusual about this particular aloe drink: No sodium benzoate. I hate sodium benzoate, a nasty preservative that has a disturbing habit of changing structure and turning into benzene, a trigger for bone cell leukemia. Plus it tastes gross. What is that garbage doing in our drinks? But I digress. "Aloe Gloe" doesn't have it, and it also doesn't have citric acid, which besides tasting bad helps sodium benzoate do its little cancer quick change (they are frequently together). Instead we have malic acid, usually derived from apples. Perhaps it's the malic acid that gives "Aloe Gloe" a discernible apple-like flavor. Or it could be the "natural flavors" listed on the label.This aloe drink tastes pretty decent (a sliding scale to be sure), kind of like a Pink Lady apple. The product is made with aloe powder and not pure aloe juice, and is diluted with water. There is both cane sugar and stevia, and I think it would have been better to drop the stevia as it has a bit of that yick stevia aftertaste. The sweetener combination is a case of trying to please everyone while probably pleasing no one: Those avoiding sugar won't like the sugar content (though it's only 4 grams per serving) and those who hate stevia (or like my sister have an allergy) won't like the distinctive stevia taste. Why put them in there at all? Does everything need to be super sweet?  But again, I digress.So to sum up: Aloe powder instead of pure juice, 4 grams of sugar per serving but also with a fairly strong taste of stevia, semi-pleasant tasting, probably not terribly medicinal. If you need the real deal, then better to get the real deal (I like Lakewood Organics Aloe). But if you like stevia and the flavor of apples, you might want to give it a try.GRADE: B/B-

reviewText: Like some other reviewers, I've heard that coconut oil is a good choice when cooking.  Why buy good olive oil only to destroy its benefits through heating it?Mostly, I try to add olive oil after I've cooked the food, but sometimes you need a little oil, such as with browning onions or a mire poix.  The other brands of coconut oil I've tried impart more coconut flavor than this brand; that's fine when Thai food is on the menu, for example; not so great with some other types of cooking.I've always liked the Jarrow brand, so I'm more inclined to trust that this product is indeed what it says on the label.About halfway through this jar, I'm pleased with this product.

Got these yesterday and needless to day the bag is gone! They are the perfect mix of a shortbread cookie  with hints of figs and honey! The  figs are candied so they have a nice caramelized crunch as you eat the cookie, couldn't really taste the honey, which is cool, because I'm not a honey freak, all in all this cookie was delish and i would highly recommend it!

My family and I have always enjoyed seafood, and sardines are no exception.  My in-laws introduced me to King Oscar brand of canned sardines ten years ago, and we've never purchased anything else.  We were glad to sample these sardines in Extra Virgin Olive Oil with Jalapeño Peppers.Likes:*Firm, finely textured sardines with no pungent fishy smell and taste.*We recently made some fish tacos with these King Oscar sardines.  Muy delicioso.*We enjoyed the taste of sardines in extra virgin olive oil with the hot Jalapeño Peppers.*Sardines taste good and are a good source of Omega-3s, calcium, and other vitamins and minerals.*Available in a convenient 12-pack from Amazon for a good price.Bottom Line:For all lovers of seafood, these King Oscar brand canned sardines are unbeatable.
summary: Good tasting sardines with a dash of Jalapeño Peppers.

Since I am a hearty eater, I would consider this meal creation a snack or side dish to an already prepared dinner because the serving size is very small.  According to the label it has 340 calories (50 of which are fat calories) and the package advertises that you get 30% of your daily grains, 20% of your daily vegetables, and 15% of your daily meat in this one dish.The PROS:- Good as snack or side dish- Tastey with a little spiciness or "kick" to it- Easy to prepare (microwave 3-1/2 minutes for the pasta and 1/2 minute for the sauce)- Unit comes with built in strainer to drain pastaThe CONS:- Portion really too small for a meal.- The center tab on the sauce tray is only to be used for lifting the sauce tray out of the package.  It is not for also pulling back the plastic covering on the sauce tray. I would have preferred if it had this dual purpose as it is a little difficult to peel back the plastic on that tray.- There is entirely too much packaging and plastic.  The top acts as a strainer, the base acts as a pot and the sauce tray acts like a double boiler.  All these items are made of really nice hard plastic that stands up wonderfully in the microwave.  For such a small portion, you have to ask yourself is it worth it to clutter our environment with all this throw-away plastic.Because of the amount of pasta in comparison to all the plastic you need to package it in, I rate this item four stars.
summary: Great Snack but packaging not healthy for environment

If you are like me and mourned the loss of Crystal Light Pure drink mixes (they were relatively inexpensive and easily purchased from your local big box grocery stores, but are a discontinued product now) we finally have a replacement! I actually like these better as they have unique flavors. I really like both the Black Cherry and Peach Lemonade... the Mango Orange is so-so but not bad, just not as good as the other two flavors.As long as there isn't a price hike, I plan on buying these on a regular basis.

I had gotten used to drinking theRockstar Zero Carb Energy Drink, which comes in a blue can, but unfortunately, my local grocery store ran out of it. All they had in stock was this version, so I decided to give it a try. I personally like the flavor. It tastes like cream soda to me, and it is neither too sweet nor too tart, with a nice level of carbonation.The only kind of soda I've consumed for decades is diet, so the diet taste doesn't bother me, and it has no aftertaste. However, since artificial sweeteners pose health concerns, I would not feel comfortable drinking or eating anything containing them on a daily basis. Likewise for artificial and natural flavors. When I really need an energy boost, however, the Rockstar products seem to work much better than coffee, providing a boost without the jitters coffee gives me.This can has 16 ounces. The recommended serving size printed on the can is 8 ounces, which has 10 calories. I personally only need 4 ounces to get a good energy boost, even when feeling extremely sleepy in a mid-afternoon slump. I refrigerate the leftover energy drink in a SodaStream Penguin glass carafe to preserve the carbonation because I have several on hand that I use for my Sodastream Penguin soda maker.Here is the ingredient list on the can: Carbonated water, citric acid, taurine, natural and artificial flavors, sodium citrate, caffeine, caramel color, benzoic acid, sorbic acid, acesulfame potassium, sucralose, l-carnitine, inositol, niacinamide, calcium panthothenate, milk thistle extract, ginkgo biloba leaf extract, guarana seed extract, panax ginseng root extract, riboflavin, pyridoxine hydrochloride, cyanocobalamin.I was favorably impressed with many of the ingredients of this drink, with several exceptions (see above and below). I understand that Rockstar's original flavors of energy drink are extremely high in calories, about 240 or so for a 16-ounce can this size, and many people do not want to drink that many calories.I researched all of the ingredients, many of which might not be immediately recognizable to most consumers--those that are obvious (such as carbonated water), I have not listed below:Citric acid - This is a natural acid found in many fruits which is a safe preservative.Taurine - This is an amino acid popular with athletes. Research indicates it is a potent antioxidant supportive of nerve, brain, and heart function and cardiovascular health in general. It has also been used to treat diabetes, retinal damage and diabetes.Natural flavor - The definition of natural flavor under the Code of Federal Regulations is: "The essential oil, oleoresin, essence or extractive, protein hydrolysate, distillate, or any product of roasting, heating or enzymolysis, which contains the flavoring constituents derived from a spice, fruit or fruit juice, vegetable or vegetable juice, edible yeast, herb, bark, bud, root, leaf or similar plant material, meat, seafood, poultry, eggs, dairy products, or fermentation products thereof, whose significant function in food is flavoring rather than nutritional" (21CFR101.22). That essentially means that natural flavor is derived from a real food, but the process by which it is derived is unexplained and there is no way to know how safe or healthy a natural flavoring is.Artificial flavor - The definition of artificial flavor under the Code of Federal Regulations is: "Any substance, the function of which is to impart flavor, which is not derived from a spice, fruit or fruit juice, vegetable or vegetable juice, edible yeast, herb, bark, bud, root, leaf or similar plant material, meat, fish, poultry, eggs, dairy products, or fermentation products thereof. " (21CFR101.22). That essentially means that artificial flavor is derived from non-food substances, that is, chemicals created in a lab. Even more so than for a "natural" flavor, because the process by which it is derived is unexplained, there is no way for the consumer to decide how safe the artificial flavor is.Benzoic Acid - This is a widely used food preservative created from a chemical process involving toluene, a benzene derivative. Benzene is a highly toxic chemical, so this particular ingredient is dubious at best, and there is no need for it because the product contains multiple other preservatives. A major concern for benzoic acid in soft drinks is when ascorbic acid (vitamin C) is also present as a preservative, which combines with benzoic acid and causes it to revert to benzene. Fortunately there is no ascorbic acid in this drink or it would be too dangerous to consume.Sorbic Acid - This is an antimicrobial agent frequently used in food and drink to prevent the growth of mold, yeast, and fungi, which not only taste bad, but are toxic.Acesulfame potassium and sucralose - These are artificial sweeteners, whose safety is debated.l-Carnitine - This is an amino acid which functions in the body as an antioxidant. It has been found to normalize glucose in the blood and is beneficial to heart health.Inositol - This is a B vitamin produced naturally in the body. It participates in the action of serotonin an, as such, may naturally elevate the mood.Niacinamide - This is the technical term for vitamin B3. It helps the body maintain blood sugar levels and improve the strength and recovery from fatigue of muscles. It is also prescribed by doctors to decrease blood lipid levels and relieve joint pain.Calcium Panthothenate - This is the technical term for vitamin B-5. This vitamin, especially when taken in conjunction with the complete complex of B vitamins, can increase energy levels, improve brain health, promote the healing of wounds, increase immune function, regulate the production of hormones, and improve the mood.Milk thistle extract - This is an herb known to detoxify the liver and improve its function.Ginkgo biloba leaf extract - There have been decades of research on this powerful, healing herb. Its beneficial actions include: antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, healing of the cardiovascular system and neuropathy, and a stimulating effect on neurotransmitters. It is known to improve mental functioning, particularly the memory.Guarana Seed Extractive - This is a natural stimulant high in caffeine produced from the berries of an Amazonian shrub.Panax ginseng root extract - This plant substance improves concentration, memory, and physical stamina. It is known as an "adaptogen" because it improves general well-being and health. It is a mood elevator without the dangerous side effects of of anxiety and depression drugs. It has been used to treat chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) and fibromyalgia, to boost the immune system, and to treat lung infections associated with cystic fibrosis. It fights cancer, anemia, diabetes, asthma, fever, nerve pain, joint pain, dizziness, headaches, hot flashes due to menopause, and hangover.Riboflavin - Riboflavin (vitamin B2) aids in red blood cell production and assists the body to release energy from carbohydrates. The body does not make this vitamin. It must be consumed. It is readily available in dairy, meat, legumes, nuts, eggs and green leafy vegetables.Pyridoxine hydrochloride - This is vitamin B6. The main benefits it provides that are useful in an energy drink are increasing cognitive function and reducing muscle cramps. It has a huge list of other benefits as well. It is known to boost immune function and be helpful in the treatment of anemia, heart disease, high cholesterol, PMS, nausea from pregnancy, post-partum deprepression, "hot flashes" of menopause, ADD, Alzheimer's, Down syndrome, autism, diabetes, migraine headaches, asthma, carpal tunnel syndrome, arthritis, allergies, skin conditions, infertility, infections of all kinds, prevention of cancer, and overcoming the side effects of radiation and dangerous prescription drugs (though in much higher doses than in this drink, and with a doctor's supervision).Cyanocobalamin - This is vitamin B12. It is vital for the body to convert carbohydrates into glucose, which leads to energy production, which prevents fatigue. It helps keep the nervous system healthy. It reduces depression, stress and brain shrinkage. It promotes a healthy digestive system. It protects against heart disease, stroke and high blood pressure. It is essential for healthy skin, hair and nails. It helps prevent cancer.

I bought these for my husband who is gluten sensitive, dairy sensitive, and diabetic. Although they are not sugar free, they have a low enough level of sugar that my husband can eat them.He really likes them and really enjoyed having them as an option.  He said they don't taste exactly like glutenated graham crackers, but are good on their own.  He really enjoyed making smores with them.  We used the marshmallow creme by Bountiful Harvest and dark chocolate by YC Chocolate - both gluten and dairy free.For the person who asked what ingredients are in these crackers:Casein free. Dairy free. Lactose free. Peanut free. Nut free. Tree nut free. Gluten free has never tasted so good. Produced in a dedicated gluten free, wheat free, dairy free, peanut free and tree nut free facility.IngredientsPea Starch, Non Hydrogenated Shortening (Palm Fruit and/or Canola), Potato Starch, Brown Rice Flour, Brown Sugar, Sweet Rice Flour, Tapioca Starch, Water, Rice Bran, Sugar, Blackstrap Molasses, Honey, Glucose, Salt, Sodium Bicarbonate, Pea Protein, Vanilla, Sodium Carboxy Methylcellulose, Pea Fibre, Guar Gum, Inulin, Soy Lecithin, Mono Calcium Phosphate.WarningsAllergy Alert: May contain traces of eggs.
summary: Good for smores and taste good, too
